question_text: Why are memory modules such as DDR2, DDR3, and DDR4 not physically interchangeable?
answer_options: They use different voltages that damage mismatched motherboards
They require BIOS updates before installation
Their notches (keys) are located differently to prevent improper installation
They use different chip packaging materials
correct_answer: Their notches (keys) are located differently to prevent improper installation
explanation: Each memory generation (DDR2, DDR3, DDR4) has a unique notch location. This mechanical keying prevents incompatible modules from being installed into the wrong motherboard slot.
